text.title: Concern over Berlusconi's health

main.p: There has been growing speculation about the health of Italy's prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, ahead of one of the most challenging tasks of his political career - next week's crucial EU summit in Brussels to decide on the European constitution.
For the second time in two weeks, it was announced on Tuesday that he had put off high-level official engagements.
Aides said he was suffering from a recurring gastro-intestinal ailment and was unable to attend two meetings which had been arranged to prepare for the summit.

Mr Berlusconi was meant to have had talks on Tuesday with the Cypriot president, Tassos Papadopoulos, and Denmark's prime minister, Anders Fogh Rasmussen. Last week, he put off a visit to India for the same reason.
His officials called it a "slight" indisposition. But in political circles in Rome there is a growing suspicion that it could be more serious.
Mr Berlusconi, who had an operation for prostate cancer six years ago, has been virtually absent from public life for almost a month.
His last significant public appearance was at a press conference on November 6 with President Vladimir Putin of Russia.
Italy holds the presidency of the EU and Mr Berlusconi and his ministers are keen to crown their stint with a deal on the constitution at the summit beginning on December 12.
The Italian leader is to fly to Paris today to meet his French and Spanish counterparts, Jean-Pierre Raffarin and Jos√© Maria Aznar.
It seemed last night that he would keep this appointment. His aides said he had been well enough to have a meeting with the Romanian prime minister, Adrian Nastase, yesterday.
Last month, Mr Berlusconi, 67, said he had received a clean bill of health during an annual check-up. He was operated on for cancer 1997, but did not reveal his illness until three years later.
